title: Erdős #550: Ramsey Numbers for Trees and Multipartite Graphs
description: For T a tree on n vertices and G = K_{m₁,...,mₖ}, prove R(T,G) ≤ (χ(G)-1)(R(T,K_{m₁,m₂})-1)+m₁. Chvátal (1977): R(T,Kₘ) = (m-1)(n-1)+1 is the foundational result.

overview.historicalContext: This problem extends Chvátal's 1977 exact result R(T,Kₘ) = (m-1)(n-1)+1 to complete multipartite graphs. The conjecture proposes a recursive bound using the chromatic number χ(G) = k and the bipartite Ramsey number R(T,K_{m₁,m₂}). It appears as #16 in the Ramsey Theory problems collection.
overview.problemStatement: Let m₁ ≤ ⋯ ≤ mₖ and n be sufficiently large. If T is a tree on n vertices and G is the complete multipartite graph K_{m₁,...,mₖ}, prove that R(T,G) ≤ (χ(G)-1)(R(T,K_{m₁,m₂})-1)+m₁.
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize trees, complete multipartite graphs, Ramsey numbers, Chvátal's theorem, the main conjecture, special cases (paths, stars, bounded degree), probabilistic lower bounds, extremal constructions, and asymptotic behavior.
keyInsights: The bound reduces to Chvátal when G = Kₘ
Burr's conjecture for bounded-degree trees is proved
For fixed m, R(T_n, Kₘ) ~ (m-1)n asymptotically

sections.title: The Conjecture
sections.summary: The conjectured bound for multipartite G

conclusion.summary: This formalization captures Erdős Problem #550 on Ramsey numbers for trees and complete multipartite graphs. The conjecture extends Chvátal's exact result R(T,Kₘ) = (m-1)(n-1)+1 to multipartite graphs using a recursive bound involving the chromatic number.
conclusion.implications: The problem connects tree embedding with Ramsey theory. Chvátal's theorem provides the complete answer for complete graphs, but the extension to multipartite graphs remains open. Special cases like bounded-degree trees (Burr's conjecture) have been resolved.
openQuestions: Does the conjectured bound hold for all sufficiently large n?
What is the exact value of R(T, K_{m,m}) for general trees?
Can the bound be improved for specific tree families?
What is the relationship to Turán extremal graphs?
